content.webTitle: 'Cancer patients like me are just getting forgotten about'

fields.headline: 'Cancer patients like me are just getting forgotten about'
fields.bodyText: It’s the same for everybody waiting for a life-saving cancer operation: this coronavirus is taking over. They diagnosed me with oesophageal cancer in January and were going to give me four treatments, then surgery to remove the cancer from my gullet, then four more sessions to clear any cancer they’d missed. Luckily, the chemotherapy worked and the cancer had gone from my lymph nodes, so the surgeon said I would have two more sessions, then he would schedule an operation to completely remove it, because three months after chemo it can come back. Then this pandemic came along and the operation in early May was cancelled, because I would have to be in the intensive care unit where beds are in short supply. It’s ridiculous they can’t separate patients and staff in the hospitals, to have a separate cancer wing. The whole world is understandably sympathising for coronavirus patients, but why must everything be for them? Cancer patients like me are just getting forgotten about. All people can think about is coronavirus and everybody wants to be seen to be doing their best to fight against it. I’m absolutely cross, I did lose my temper last week, but there’s nothing I can do about it. They said we’re hoping this coronavirus will die down in a few weeks and we can get you an operation. I asked: “What should I do in the meantime, go and die?” The doctor said: “Well, I can’t answer that.” It’s the not knowing. What am I going to say if they tell me they have to withdraw my treatment and there is no operation on the horizon. I have to have this operation, it’s the only way of properly getting rid of that cancer. There is only so much chemo you can have before it starts to kill white blood cells – that’s why your hair falls out. But I’m trying not to worry about it day by day. Whatever will be, will be. It’s just unfortunate I got it at the same time people got the coronavirus. I’m a married father of three children who I’m very proud of, and the government needs to do something. I need an operation. This would give me up to a 50% chance of living for at least another five years, but the cancer will kill me if I don’t get it removed.
